siteMetadata.title: NI Fuse Design System
siteMetadata.description: Documentation for the NI Fuse Design System
siteMetadata.subtitle: Fuse Design System

children.value: While group boxes can be a way to visually create relationships between controls, they can cause a simple interface to look overly complex.
Instead of group boxes, try using layout to communicate relationships. Use headings and indenting to show hierarchical relationships.  Using a separator is lighter weight and provides a cleaner look.
If you find you must use a group box:
Don’t put controls in group box labels
Don’t disable group boxes. Instead, disable all the controls inside the group box, but not the group box itself.
Watch for redundancy with the group box label and the control labels.
This style of group box is not yet available as a control. However, you can use a
in XAML to get this style.
<!--Place the style in the resources area of your XAML file-->
<!--Place this in the layout (canvas, grid, etc.) section of your XAML file-->

These checkboxes are examples of layout in a group box. It uses a stack panel for layout. You may need to tweak the margins depending on the controls you use. The content of this group box should have 10px of space on the left, right and bottom sides.
